awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Regolith size sorting technology for space resource utilization
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a core enabling technology for lunar in situ resource utilization: the ability to sort “Moon dirt” (lunar regolith) by particle size. Size sorting is an important capability for nearly all in situ resource utilization activities that use lunar regolith as a feedstock material. By enabling raw lunar regolith to be sorted into multiple streams by particle size, the technology will provide appropriate feedstocks for lunar oxygen extraction systems, lunar 3-dimensional printers, and other applications. The use of the Moon’s resources is a disruptive capability that will enable missions there to “live off the land,” making the development of this technology important for government agencies and industry alike. The many potential applications of lunar in situ resource utilization promise to make this a multi-billion dollar market. 

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop and demonstrate a novel regolith size sorting system for use on the Moon that has 10x smaller volume, 5x lower mass, and greater reliability than traditional devices such as vibratory sieves (vibrating screens). The project will also develop a new lunar regolith simulant designed to mimic real lunar regolith’s particle size distribution and flow properties. While size sorting on Earth is well understood, size sorting dynamics on the Moon are not well understood and size sorting is identified as a gap in lunar technology road maps. The team will address performance and scalability risks by developing a device which uses rotating paddles to provide centrifugal motion to sieve the particles through a screen. A variety of centrifuge aspect ratios, paddle configurations, and rotational speeds will be tested to optimize throughput. Additionally, blinding (plugging) of the sieve by regolith particles will be characterized at different rotational speeds and addressed, if necessary, by developing and testing anti-blinding features on the rotating paddles, such as brushes and low-friction wipers. Finally, the device will be demonstrated to operate in lunar gravity on a parabolic aircraft flight using the new simulant.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sustainable development on the Moon will depend on the ability to extract and utilize resources directly from lunar soil, known as regolith, rather than relying only on material brought from Earth. Both government and private sectors, domestically and internationally, are advancing technologies to use lunar regolith for applications ranging from propellant production and additive manufacturing feedstock to life support replenishment. Many of these applications require regolith to be sorted into specific particle sizes, as large particles can cause mechanical failures, while certain processes that melt regolith for resource extraction require very fine particles for efficiency. Additive manufacturing, especially using laser sintering, also depends on fine particle sizes. Current size-sorting technology for regolith is limited and rarely tested in conditions that represent the Moon's reduced gravity.

To address this, Interlune developed an innovative device designed to demonstrate scalable, transportable, and reliable regolith size sorting, where target particle size can be easily adjusted by changing one part of the device. Using centripetal acceleration, the device decouples the sieving process from local gravity. Regolith enters a cylindrical sorting chamber, where it is spun at high speed, ejecting finer particles through a mesh lining the chamber walls, while coarse particles exit through a trap at the chamber's base.

Interlune's device underwent extensive ground testing, followed by testing under lunar gravity (1/6 G) aboard a Zero-G parabolic flight in August 2024. For these tests, a custom regolith simulant with known particle sizes was used to validate performance. During flight testing, the device sorted regolith in lunar gravity for a total of 120 seconds, processing 5 kg of simulant and successfully separating particles smaller than 0.5 mm. This performance scales to a potential rate of 152 kg/hour, or 3,650 kg/day, surpassing the output rate NASA envisions for a full-scale production system to support a permanent Moon base. Additionally, the device operated with a low power consumption of under 100 watts, achieving a specific power usage of 0.6 Whr/kg. As expected, the device's performance was better in lunar gravity due to the longer residence time particles had in the chamber, increasing sorting efficiency before reaching the bottom trap.

The outcomes of this project indicate that Interlune's technology could meet NASA's size-sorting requirements for sustainable lunar resource utilization and could play a vital role in supporting large-scale lunar industrialization. Interlune's vision is to harvest resources from the Moon and other celestial bodies to benefit humanity on a large scale. In future project phases, Interlune aims to enhance the device's efficiency and throughput while simulating more realistic lunar conditions, such as vacuum, to prepare the technology for continuous operation in a production environment on the Moon.
